# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is how you can solve this problem in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    df[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return df
end
```
This function uses the `filter` function from DataFrames to filter out only rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Then it adds a new column named `audi_a4_type` with all values set to true. 

You can use this function like so:
```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=[ "audi", "toyota", "bmw", "mercedes", "audi", "audi"], model=["a4", "corolla", "x5", "cl", "a4 quattro", "a8"])
df_result = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
